title: India keen to take down Australia for perfect end to season : Cricket, News - India Today
text:
Cricket India keen to take down Australia for perfect end to season With the opening Test between the world's top two Test teams beginning in Pune on Thursday, the odds are stacked heavily in favour of hosts India, who have gone 19 Tests without defeat. Reuters | Posted by Jepher Christopher Nickels Indian cricket team (BCCI Photo) Highlights The odds are stacked heavily in favour of hosts India. 2 India are sitting pretty at the top of the Test rankings after six consecutive series victories. 3 The series against Australia marks the end of India's 13-Test home season. 
The Indian Test juggernaut, with Virat Kohli at the wheel, has crushed almost everything in its path over the last 18 months and Australia will have to conjure up something special if they are to upset the hosts in their four-match series. ( Kohli on Test series against Australia: Not bothered about the opposition ) 
With the opening Test between the world's top two Test teams beginning in Pune on Thursday, the odds are stacked heavily in favour of hosts India, who have gone 19 Tests without defeat. ( Kohli creates a positive environment in the dressing-room: Saha to India Today ) 
In the final phase of their bumper home season, India are sitting pretty at the top of the Test rankings after six consecutive series victories. 
Significantly, their last three home series victories, over New Zealand, England and Bangladesh, were underpinned by all-round excellence and came on fair surfaces, not the dustbowls on which India typically thrive. ( Virat Kohli won his battles against Joe Root, can he trump Steve Smith? ) 
The series against Australia marks the end of India's 13-Test home season and Kohli wants his team to maintain the level they have been playing at. 
"It's a big series for us," Kohli told reporters earlier this month. "I thought England was the biggest for us in the season but having won that 4-0 there is lot of expectation on us. 
"The way we have played our cricket as well I think we want to continue that," added India's batting mainstay. ( Five India vs Australia controversies that shook the cricketing world ) 
Earlier this month, the 28-year-old became the first cricketer to hit a double century in four consecutive Test series and his team posted 600-plus totals in three consecutive Tests, another first. ( Aussies just don't have the arsenal to walk the 'sledging' talk ) 
That middle order bat Karun Nair had to be dropped in the one-off Test against Bangladesh despite scoring a triple century in the previous match against England is another indication of the team's batting might. ( India would treat Australia like any other team, says Kumble ) 
BAG OF TRICKS 
When India bowl, Ravichandran Ashwin has done with the ball what Kohli has done with the bat. ( Tendulkar vs Australia or Kohli-Australia: Which rivalry is more fun? ) 
The off-spinner, currently the top ranked Test bowler, has been in the form of his life, becoming the quickest to the 250-wicket club after achieving the feat in just 45 Tests. ( Tendulkar a legend but hard to look past Kohli: Chris Woakes ) 
The off-spinner with his bag of tricks will torment Smith and his men, often bowling relentlessly in tandem with spin partner Ravindra Jadeja , with a shoal of fielders hanging around the blade. ( Sledging Virat Kohli will hurt Australia: David Warner ) 
Smith is aware of the challenge that awaits Australia, who have lost nine consecutive Test matches in Asia. 
"We know it's going to be difficult," he said. "India are a very good team, particularly in there home conditions here. We have prepared very well." ( Virat Kohli not Australia's only threat: 4 other concerns for Steve Smith's men ) 
Cricket Australia recruited ex-England spinner Monty Panesar and former India left-arm spinning all-rounder Sridharan Sriram to work with their slow bowlers. 
Smith will rely more on the pace duo of Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood, who would have to generate enough reverse swing to be effective on relatively docile Indian tracks. ( Steve Smith's men weakest Australian side to tour India, says Harbhajan Singh ) 
The visitors can also take heart from the fact that three of the four matches will be played on new venues -- Pune, Ranchi and Dharamsala -- which will negate some of India's home advantage.
